Award.AwardTitle: Poroelastic Wave Propagation in Anisotropic Bone

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to examine the cause-effect relationship between changes in trabecular bone microarchitecture and measured poroelastic ultrasound wave properties. The energy of an ultrasound wave propagating through a fluid-saturated porous medium such as trabecular bone creates two distinct poroelastic waves which travel with velocities and attenuations that depend on the properties of solid and fluid constituents of bone. Studies conducted under this award will use analytical, numerical and experimental approaches to determine the effect of changes in pore microarchitecture, material properties and wave frequency on the velocity and attenuation of these two waves. The proposed parametric study will investigate wave propagation properties in both experimental and finite-difference time-domain numerical simulations in 3D printed porous medium models. An anisotropic poroelastic theoretical approach will be used to distinguish the contribution of solid and fluid constituents on measured ultrasound wave signals in both 3D printed models and human trabecular bones. The long-term objective of this research is to change the technology used for the assessment of osteoporosis from the current standard of ionizing and expensive DEXA devices to lower cost, non-ionizing ultrasound systems that access microarchitecture as well as material properties.

If successful, this architectural-based approach will reveal the main microarchitectural determinants of ultrasound wave propagation in porous media, and will improve the non-invasive characterization of changes in trabecular bone during bone loss and osteoporosis. The educational component of this award focuses on developing a multidisciplinary program on bone biomechanics and biomedical imaging for undergraduate students from underrepresented groups at the City College of New York, increasing the number of course modules with numerical modeling, research design and imaging hands-on laboratory experience. The program will provide closely mentored research opportunities for undergraduate students to attract them to follow graduate studies in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current gold standard to diagnose bone loss and osteoporosis is the measurement of the Bone Mineral Density (BMD), which is a measure of the amount of mineral per total bone volume determined by Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA). However, a significant number of women diagnosed with osteoporosis based on a BMD test do not suffer fractures, whereas many women with normal BMD do. BMD measurements lack both sensitivity and specificity to effectively identify patients at risk of fracture, indicating that other factors besides bone mass density, such as bone microarchitecture and tissue mineral density, play an important role in osteoporosis.

In this study, we developed and tested an ultrasound approach that is sensitive to changes on microarchitecture and tissue mineral density, and that is thus capable of providing a better assessment of bone loss when compared with BMD by DEXA. We focused on the development of an ultrasound-based technique because ultrasound is non-ionizing, inexpensive and non-invasive. More importantly, we demonstrated that using our ultrasound approach it is possible to quantitatively measure the mass density (equivalent to BMD), trabecular bone microarchitecture, linear elastic constants and yield stress along the principal directions of trabecular microarchitecture. These mechanical properties are better descriptors of bone fragility than bone mass density.

Specifically, within the first objective of our study, we investigated the influence of bone porosity, anisotropy and tissue density parameters on ultrasound wave propagation parameters by comparing numerical wave propagation simulations using a finite-difference time-domain method with experimental wave propagation using poroelastic ultrasound tomography on 3D printed models with different porosity, anisotropy or material properties. The computer design of all the numerical models was completed in SolidWorks. The models were imported into Wave3000 software, and prepared for numerical simulation of wave propagation. Spatial location of emitter/receiver, definition of ultrasound wave source, boundary conditions and material properties were assigned to each model. The appropriate grid size and time step were determined, and numerical simulations of wave propagation using a Finite Differences in Time Domain algorithm were performed along three directions on each model, normal to the surface of the sample. For the second objective of our study, we investigated whether the proposed ultrasound approach can readily distinguish changes in the elastic properties of the solid porous structure. The drained elastic constants associated to the solid porous structure were estimated from the poroelastic ultrasound wave propagation theory and measurements of fast and slow wave measurements on 3D printed porous media models with different porosity, anisotropy and tissue density, as well as human anisotropic bone from calcanei.

Regarding the educational objective of this project, we developed a multidisciplinary program in bone biomechanics and biomedical imaging for undergraduate students, most of them from underrepresented groups in STEM and biomedical engineering. Such program has overall increased the research opportunities for undergraduates (5-6 per year), graduate students (2-4 per year) and collaboration with other faculty, as well as increased the number of courses with ultrasound and imaging hands-on lab experience available to our students. Specifically, we implemented a multidisciplinary BME research program for undergraduate students consisting of numerical modeling and hands-on tasks on bone biomechanics and biomedical imaging. We use lectures and lab experience to teach our students various methods to perform 3D ultrasound wave simulations using finite-difference time-domain and experimental testing on 3D printed porous media models. The PI has integrated ultrasound wave propagation modeling into the BME Dynamical systems and Modeling course and the Poroelasticity graduate level class. Our undergraduate students also gain valuable experience learning Computer Assisted Design and Numerical Modeling by using Solid Works, Mimics, MatLab, Abaqus and Wave3000 which are of great utility for the Senior Design Course that they take concurrently or after being in the PIs lab. 

We expect that the poroelastic ultrasound approach that we developed within this research project will allow the non-invasive assessment of porous media in both clinic (i.e. bone loss and osteoporosis) and non-destructive material testing industry (i.e. geology, new materials, etc.). In particular this technology is likely to make an impact on infrastructure by enabling the assessment of changes in bone/materials density and anisotropy in a non-invasive way. We expect this approach to help improve the specificity and selectivity of the diagnostic methods of osteoporosis and to contribute to the improvement of our understanding of several musculoskeletal diseases, their diagnosis and therapeutics, thus, positively impacting society welfare in general.
